copy that line to a new file and name it *.sh and chmod it to what?
you don't need to rename it. you need to put     #! /bin/sh   on the first line, and to chmod +x

generally speaking, if the first line of a file (we call it A) begins with #! followed by a filename (call this B), the shell tries to run B as a command, passing A as an argument. so, for shell scripts, you want B to be a shell (/bin/sh)
